channel.title: Posts on JASON JONES
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on JASON JONES

item.title: I Like It When You Call Me Large SpatialPolygonsDataFrame
item.description: Welcome to the wonderful world of R-Spatial! I really enjoy playing around with spatial data in R and for some reason find it much easier than ArcGIS (#sorrynotsorry Esri). Please keep in mind, as with everything I do in R, I am self taught and rely heavily on publicly available resources. My way of doing things may not always be the best or perfect, it is just how I was able to make sense of it.

item.title: Spatial Exploration - MUSA Masterclass
item.description: This post was inspired by the MUSA Masterclass provided very graciously by Ken Steif and James Cheshire. If you aren’t familiar with the program I would strongly encourage you to check it out - UPenn MUSA Program. I decided to use open data from the City of Raleigh for my exploration. All data can be found on The City of Raleigh’s open data portal. The primary data I am using is contained in the Raleigh Police Incidents (NIBRS) dataset.

item.title: Age Is Just A Number…Statistically Speaking
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) bulk_dat <- read_csv("https://www.dallasopendata.com/api/views/ftja-9jxd/rows.csv", col_types = cols(offensereportingofficerbadge2 = col_character(), offensebeat = col_character())) %>% mutate(offensedate = as.Date(offensedate, format = "%m/%d/%Y")) bulk_dat <- bulk_dat %>% mutate(hour = hour(offensetimeofoccurence2)) %>% mutate(age = as.integer(offenseage)) %>% mutate(month = month(offensedate)) bulk_dat %>% ggplot(aes(age)) + geom_histogram(aes(y = ..density..), binwidth = 5, color = "black", fill = "white") + geom_density(alpha = .2, fill = "blue") + geom_vline(aes(xintercept = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE)), color = "red", linetype = "dashed", size = 1) bulk_dat %>% ggplot(aes(hour)) + geom_histogram(aes(y = .

item.title: Health and Economic Impact of Storms and Severe Weather Events
item.description: Synopsis In this analysis I amd concerned with two primary points. Which event types have the greatest health impact and the greatest economic impact. I begin my work with data processing to create usable objects for results visualization. I finish my analysis with two plots and a final table. Package Load Load packages required for analysis. require(tidyverse) require(lubridate) require(kableExtra) Data Import Leveraging read_csv from the readr packackge included with tidyverse to import the dataset.

item.title: City of Raleigh Budget Sentiment Analysis
item.description: Package Import Load necessary packages and set one global option. library(tidyverse) library(pdftools) library(tidytext) library(knitr) library(kableExtra) options(stringsAsFactors = FALSE) Retrieve File Download the file from the City of Raleigh website, read that file in as a character vector, and delete the downloaded file from the directory. download.file("https://www.raleighnc.gov/content/BudgetManagement/Documents/Budget/Archive/2018/FY2018AdoptedBudget20160612.pdf", "FY2018AdoptedBudget.pdf", mode = "wb") txt = pdf_text("FY2018AdoptedBudget.pdf") unlink("FY2018AdoptedBudget.pdf") Create Data Frame Create a page number character vector, create a data frame by binding the page number character vector with the extracted text, and finally “unnest” all of the page text into individual words.
